utterances: A warning system might also automatically shut down pipelines and refineries.
The Geological Survey supported Allen's work and is studying how to use it.
The survey's Bill Leith says the hardest part may be getting a warning out fast enough.
If a second of data is collected and then transmitted over the Internet in a packet, then we've lost a second.
So one of the results of the study might be to change the way that we transmit information in order to be able to not lose that second.
That is no way for the United States to run its business and, frankly, it's not just me saying this.

If you look at the leaders of Congress, both Democrat and Republican, almost all of them are acknowledging that Congress has to act to extend our borrowing authority and that they should do it as quickly as possible.
And I am very hopeful that they are going to do that in a very short period of time.
That does seem to be the message from House Speaker John Boehner.
He has said we should not default on our debt.
We shouldn't even get close to it.
So how are you reading the signals you're getting from the Republican leadership?
Does it seem that they're far less hostile to this than they have been in the past?
Well, I think that everyone went through last October and saw that the combination of the government shutdown and the near default caused an enormous amount of economic volatility and it is not good.
The president's been very clear and it is not just a question about this president and this Congress.

We can't be in a place where the question of whether or not the United States pays its bills is something that every six or 12 months becomes a kind of demand for concessions because it cannot be a tolerable idea that the United States would not pay its bills.
Since 1789, we've always paid all our bills.
And this Congress has to do what every other Congress has done and make that possible.
Secretary Lew, if you look at the long-term prospects here, even though annual deficits are shrinking, the U.S.
long-term debt is now over 17 trillion dollars.
It's about, I think, 73 percent of GDP.
How big a problem do you consider that to be?
Look, I think if you look at the path that we've taken over the last five years, we've reduced the deficit, cut in half.
We've stabilized the deficit as a percentage of GDP, kept it coming down and we've stabilized debt as a percentage of GDP.

Obviously, there are longer-term issues that the president has spend much time looking at, negotiating with Congress about, but you don't get to the long term if you don't get through the short term in a successful way.
The short term, we're doing very well.

We're bringing the deficit down and, frankly, we need to worry more about growing opportunities for Americans to find good middle-class jobs because that's ultimately the path towards the strongest fiscal policy.
I've been talking with U.S.
Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew.
Secretary Lew, thanks very much.
Good to be with you, Melissa.
From NPR News it's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish.
And I'm Melissa Block.
One couple wore slinky evening dresses, another tie-dye T-shirts and jeans.
One couple exchanged their vows in sign language.
It was a same-sex wedding marathon yesterday at city hall in Minneapolis, as Minnesota's law legalizing gay marriage went into effect.
From midnight to 7:00 in the morning, Minneapolis Mayor R.
T.
Rybak officiated at 46 weddings on the marble stairs inside city hall.
Mayor Rybak is taking a break from his wedding duties today and he joins me from city hall.
Mayor Rybak, welcome to the program.
How's your voice doing today?
MAYOR R.
T.
RYBAK: My voice is doing good and I haven't married anybody since, so I think I'm back to real life.
Well, let's go back.
This all started back in May when the Minnesota Senate voted to recognize gay marriage rights.
And you shouted something into the rotunda of the capitol.
What was it that you shouted?
I said, if this thing passes, come on down to city hall and I'll marry you.
I didn't quite realize how much work that would be for my staff around me but it was also an incredible labor of love.
Did the first of those 46 marriages that you performed feel different from the last ones?
I mean, did something start out feeling very historic and by the end it felt routine?
Well, when we did the first wedding, it was obviously historic and deeply significant.
When I started the second, I started it by saying to the crowd, now we begin the process of making something that's been historic become the routine.
And that, I think, is very important.
And certainly by the end of the night it felt different.
However, we made a huge effort not to make this a conveyor belt of love.
And I studied up a lot on the couples before and read their bios.

In between weddings I would run up the marble staircase to the second floor, meet them, talk to them for a couple of minutes, really get grounded on why they were doing it, come back down the steps, take my position.
Then they would come down, then we'd start all over again.
And we did this, you know, 46 times.
The reason that was important is that people shouldn't have to wait a minute longer after waiting all those years.
But they should also know that this wasn't just them getting rammed through but it was really about the uniqueness of each of them and, boy, did that come out.
And what were some of the things you heard in those conversations that struck you about the couples and the stories that they told you?
I overwhelmingly heard that most never expected this to happen in their lifetime.
I heard wide varieties of why people got married, many of the ones that you hear in any other situation.
But I think in this case there were some who knew there were 515 pieces of Minnesota law tied to marriage.
And so, their health care, their home, et cetera, mattered.
There were some people who talked about some range of emotion that I guess you could summarize by saying they wanted to be treated just like everyone else.
And Kathy(ph) and Margaret(ph), the first couple we married, talked to me about when they were filling out the application.
Kathy was coming to work for the city, actually.
She filled out the paperwork.
It was the day after her honeymoon, after her commitment ceremony and she had to fill out the box - single.
These things are about law but they are about the idea of being able to see people together.
And I think how people see you through their eyes matters.
I saw people look in the eyes of somebody they loved and it change at all because of a marriage, but it did change how other people look through other eyes.
Well, there's at least one conservative group in Minnesota that says it will work to defeat the state representatives who voted for the gay marriage bill.
Is it fair to say, do you think, that the support for same-sex marriage that you see there in the Twin Cities is not shared in a good part of the state?
John Singleton was involved in a very serious car accident here in Los Angeles.
Unfortunately, a pedestrian was killed.
Yeah.
We have been working for about a year now pulling black bloggers together to address many of the issues that are going on in the African-American (unintelligible).
Around issues of color, arousal, bigotry, racism, conflicts within the community.
And really community building.
Changing the way people look at African-Americans as well.
So we've come together as black bloggers and have said hey listen, we tired of other people addressing our concerns and seeing us in a different way.
We need to get out there and communicate it the way we feel is necessary.
And that's what we do as African-American bloggers.
Now, you guys, what about this conference, anyone going?
Oh, no, not me.
No, I'm not able to.
I'm working on a project up here so I'm not able to down there, but I would like to.
I think it's a good thing for everyone to get together down there, and the African-American bloggers to talk and exchange ideas and physically meet each other.
A lot of us talk to each other online and maybe through email or phone calls, but I think it's a good thing for everyone to get together and talk about the issues of the African-American community.
Especially with this election going on.
And, you know, just maybe make some connections and work towards getting information out and doing different things with the blogosphere that we have.
Are you disappointed that you won't be able to go?
Yeah, I'm really disappointed.
Yeah, I am too personally.
I mean I've met a lot of people - I've been emailing people, I've networked with a lot of people through the Internet, so I was just kind of curious to see, you know, who these people were.
To put faces to these blogs.
So on my part, yes, I am kind of disappointed that I'm not able to go.
You know, bloggers are not exactly known as herd animals.
I mean, the people who are tend to be people who are brought together by more commercial blogs like Gawker.
And, you know, and sometimes non-profit blogs, but it's also one of those things - one of the things that has made it really popular, I believe, is that people can do it on their own.
Do you think that there should be some kind of more organized you know, Richard, association of black bloggers?
Is there one I don't know about?
No, if there is I don't know about it either.

But I think it would be - I think it would be good if we had some type of central, not authority per se, but a central group of bloggers that we could, you know, I guess coordinate with when we are talking about specific issues or if we're trying to get action on a certain thing.
Maybe a crime that happened that's not getting enough attention.
Or maybe something in politics that we want to try to forward.

It would be good to have a central group of people from different ideologies that we could say OK, look, this happened and we want to shine a light on this and how should we do it, or how should we petition and kind of organize things in that way.
I think that it would be a good thing if we had something like that.
But I thought AfroSphere has been able to do that on some level.

I mean, I'm also a member of the AfroSphere and there's been a lot of issues that've been brought to my attention that, you know, don't pop up in television and print that I've learned about online through other black bloggers.
I feel like AfroSphere is trying to do something like that.
Yeah, I think they are.
And I will concur that the AfroSphere has been doing a lot.
I know with Jena Six and the sister that was down there in Texas.
And right now we're gearing up for another effort which probably both of you all know about, but I'm not going to announce here, but you'll hear about it in the next couple of days.
The AfroSphere...
Oh, come on.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Come on.
Now, if most people have heard about it, tell our audience.
Well, the black bloggers - well there's a black bloggers' organization called, if I'm not mistaken, Black AfroSphere Bloggers Association.
And then there is the AfroSphere bloggers group, which is a group of black bloggers.
I guess we're numbering about 140 now, and we continue to grow.
We're political bloggers group to some degree, but at the same time, a social activist bloggers group, and we come together as a think tank essentially.
And one of the things that we're taking a look at is the issue of - and I should be ashamed of myself, but I'm going to do it - the issue of tasering.
The tasing of many African-Americans across America.
And it's a issue that is really important and current public policy is not good with regards to police and what they're doing in African-American communities.
So it's something that the Afrosphere will be addressing shortly.
So it sounds like your mandate goes well outside of OK, well, what's up with technology?
It goes into social issues.
MR.
ROCK: Oh yeah, big time social issues.
You know, with the Jena Six, we were actively involved in rousing the people out there that do actually read bloggers.
And the good thing about blogging as well is the fact that Google has now used bloggers in a different way too.
They actually allow for anyone that Googles an issue, it goes to the blog as well.
All right.
I'm going to ask you guys an incredibly impolite question.
They say, you know, at dinner parties never ask about religion or money.
So this is a money question.
Are any of you guys making money off of your blogs?
Define money.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The thing you spend to get food?
